quoteFirst: Augustine, where Menéndez decided to establish his base. They sailed northward again the next day, and
quoteLast: their lookouts sighted four ships on the horizon. A sudden thunder shower obscured them temporarily from view, followed by a calm that lasted until evening.

quoteFirst: and unless the weather is very bad they should be allowed to go out every day for the sake of exercise. In the cold season they should not be taken to the fields before ten o'clock in the morning, and remain for four or five hours; they should then be made to drink, and
quoteTime: about three o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: be reconducted home. In spring and autumn, on the contrary, they should be taken out as soon as the sun has dissipated the moisture and hoar frost, and not taken back again till near sun-set.
title:

quoteLast: , he suddenly burst into tears, and said with a loud cry, "Oh, forsake me not!" I went to his bed-side, when he grasped my hand, and presently, by his eyes and countenance, I found that he was in prayer.

quoteLast: we left the boisterous sea to play havoc with others, and we were in the Dardanelles, where we found smoother waters, and the dining-room became a place of comfort, and the deck was filled with people.
title: From Vermont to Damascus

quoteFirst: --Very fine, this! Bring Scrippture among your Pounds, Shillings, & Pence--Very fine, young black Coat--Don't be too fast, Madam, I've got a Gown on, & my Hair is cu'd--On the 4: of July 1774.
quoteLast: , I was sitting alone in my Chamber, in Virginia, thinking--Among many other Conclusions I remember well, it was determined in my mind that this same Laura who is now so much in my Debt, is actually worth 50,000£ Sterling, pr Annum--Where is the Impropriety then, of my mentioning Solomon's Advice?--Does it now hurt your Conscience, Madam?--
title: Journal and Letters of Philip Vickers Fithian: A Plantation Tutor of the Old Dominion, 1773-1774.
author: Fithian, Philip Vickers, 1747-1776; Farish, Hunter Dickinson, 1897-1945 [Editor]; Kredel, Fritz, 1900-1973 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Out of thirteen that had lain there the day before, there were now but two ships afloat in Apia harbour, and one of these was doomed to be the bane of the other.
quoteLast: the _Trenton_ parted one cable, and shortly after a second. It was sought to keep her head to wind with storm-sails and by the ingenious expedient of filling the rigging with seamen; but in the fury of the gale, and in that sea, perturbed alike by the gigantic billows and the volleying discharges of the rivers, the rudderless ship drove down stern foremost into the inner basin; ranging, plunging, and striking like a frightened horse; drifting on destruction for herself and bringing it to others.
title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 17
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis, 1850-1894; Lang, Andrew, 1844-1912 [Other]
